update.description: This pull request contains fixes to some issues that were found by our server running Coverity. You may want to filter some of them.
update.title: Fix coverity issues

content.raw: One more [pull request](https://bitbucket.org/ocrave/ign-math/pull-requests/2) @ocrave
content.html: One more pull request @ocrave

content.raw:
Smart pointers are definitely more convenient when it comes to memory management, but I also don't find this to be the primary argument against raw pointers. We have been managing memory effectively for decades, the problem with pointers usually arises around ownership of the pointer. Memory management and ownership are related, but they are not the same beast.

In this pull request, the ownership of the pointer is very clear. This is why I was arguing for raw pointers. However, the move mechanism in c++11 changed my mind.
content.html:
Smart pointers are definitely more convenient when it comes to memory management, but I also don't find this to be the primary argument against raw pointers. We have been managing memory effectively for decades, the problem with pointers usually arises around ownership of the pointer. Memory management and ownership are related, but they are not the same beast.

In this pull request, the ownership of the pointer is very clear. This is why I was arguing for raw pointers. However, the move mechanism in c++11 changed my mind.

content.raw: Yes, I just meant that needing to call delete opens way for errors like that to slip in.
content.html: Yes, I just meant that needing to call delete opens way for errors like that to slip in.

content.raw:
I found a good reason to back up Steve's argument. For those interested, it's related to move constructors. If we eventually implement a move constructor, then it's easier and cleaner to transfer ownership using the overloaded `operator=` in `std::unique_ptr`. 

[Source 1](http://scrupulousabstractions.tumblr.com/post/37576903218/cpp11style-no-new-delete0

[Move constructor](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/move_constructor)

[Unique ptr owner transfer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/memory/unique_ptr/operator%3D)

So, let's go with unique pointers, and disable warnings.
content.html:
I found a good reason to back up Steve's argument. For those interested, it's related to move constructors. If we eventually implement a move constructor, then it's easier and cleaner to transfer ownership using the overloaded operator= in std::unique_ptr.

[Source 1](http://scrupulousabstractions.tumblr.com/post/37576903218/cpp11style-no-new-delete0

Move constructor

Unique ptr owner transfer

So, let's go with unique pointers, and disable warnings.

content.raw:
Raw pointers make a lot of sense in certain circumstances, such as when implementing your own data class.

I take Herb's suggestions seriously, but I'm also not inclined to follow everything that he says.
content.html:
Raw pointers make a lot of sense in certain circumstances, such as when implementing your own data class.

I take Herb's suggestions seriously, but I'm also not inclined to follow everything that he says.

content.raw:
I would prefer keeping the unique pointers and disabling the C4251. I liked Herb Sutter's suggestion from a cppcon video to use smart pointers so you never have to call delete. Disabling the C4251 warnings is a [common response in PIMPL code](http://stackoverflow.com/a/32098634).

@ocrave sorry to drag you into a philosophical debate
content.html:
I would prefer keeping the unique pointers and disabling the C4251. I liked Herb Sutter's suggestion from a cppcon video to use smart pointers so you never have to call delete. Disabling the C4251 warnings is a common response in PIMPL code.

@ocrave sorry to drag you into a philosophical debate

content.raw: I don't believe this is an issue here. The pull request listed above deletes the pointers in the destructor, which is where the `unique_ptr` would go out of scope as well.
content.html: I don't believe this is an issue here. The pull request listed above deletes the pointers in the destructor, which is where the unique_ptr would go out of scope as well.

content.raw: One catch about using raw opaque pointers is that we have to make sure they're deleted in the destructor after all other members. Recently we found a [problem](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/commits/62aae1c1e2eb) in Gazebo where a publisher pointer was being cleaned up after the raw pointer and that caused occasional crashes.
content.html: One catch about using raw opaque pointers is that we have to make sure they're deleted in the destructor after all other members. Recently we found a problem in Gazebo where a publisher pointer was being cleaned up after the raw pointer and that caused occasional crashes.

content.raw: Here is a [pull request](https://bitbucket.org/ocrave/ign-math/pull-requests/1)
content.html: Here is a pull request

content.raw: We should go back to using raw pointers. The pointers are not exposed via the API, and the memory can be easily managed ourselves.
content.html: We should go back to using raw pointers. The pointers are not exposed via the API, and the memory can be easily managed ourselves.

content.raw: For reference, we've [disabled](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/260/fix-all-windows-warnings/diff) C4251 warnings on sdformat.
content.html: For reference, we've disabled C4251 warnings on sdformat.

content.raw:
There are two warnings on windows related to `unique_ptr`s:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/106/warnings34Result/

Your thoughts @nkoenig ?
content.html:
There are two warnings on windows related to unique_ptrs:

  • http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/106/warnings34Result/

Your thoughts @nkoenig ?

content.raw: For the SignalStats class defining a proper copy constructor and copy assignment operator that allocates a new pimpl strutture instead of just copyng the pimpl pointer should solve che issue.

content.raw:
This branch has a [failing test](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/38/testReport/(root)/Results/test_ran/):

~~~
45: [ RUN      ] Vector3StatsTest.Vector3Stats
45: Unable to InsertStatistic [maxAbs] since it has already been inserted.
45: Unable to InsertStatistic [maxAbs] since it has already been inserted.
45: Unable to InsertStatistic [maxAbs] since it has already been inserted.
45: Unable to InsertStatistic [maxAbs] since it has already been inserted.
45: Unable to InsertStatistic [maxAbs] since it has already been inserted.
45: Unable to InsertStatistic [maxAbs] since it has already been inserted.
45: Unable to InsertStatistic [maxAbs] since it has already been inserted.
45: Unable to InsertStatistic [maxAbs] since it has already been inserted.
45/48 Test #45: UNIT_Vector3Stats_TEST ...........***Exception: SegFault  0.24 sec
~~~

I'm guessing this is related to the changes to SignalStats.cc. Also, I think this is related to #38. @traversaro do you have an idea for the right way to fix this?
